text: So, three crystals, one machine, and a few jumping puzzles. That's all there is. You might be sitting there thinking that eventually all of this will lead to something, perhaps to a deeper gameplay loop, or a narrative point, a message. You may even think that there will be a grand twist at the end. And I hope that you are right, because at the time of writing this, I don't have anything. I'm just improvising, filling this arbitrary game world with arbitrary items, adding piece after piece, just to give you something more to chew on. But what is meaningful game content anyways? All games are fictional, detached from our real lives, and so by nature, the content is also arbitrary. A game can contain anything, any goal or object. Surely one can argue that certain games deliver more meaningful experiences than others through more coherent gameplay systems. But in the end, you're always just sitting there at your computer, pushing buttons, and listening to some guy rambling about their fictional world. Listening to me rambling about this world, this world that I'm creating.
